section.name: Introduction
section.t: This document defines a Per-Message Compression Extension for the WebSocket Protocol based on the Zstandard compression format .

This extension is modeled on the "permessage-deflate" extension defined in . It attempts as much as possible to present a compatible interface to its users, differing only internally (primarily in the use of a different underlying compression scheme and then how it maps the same options as the "permessage-deflate" extension to the configuration of Zstandard).

section.name: WebSocket Extension Name
section.t: IANA is requested to register the following WebSocket extension name in the "WebSocket Extension Name Registry" defined in .
The "permessage-zstd" extension name is used in the "Sec-WebSocket-Extensions" header in the WebSocket opening handshake to negotiate use of the "permessage-zstd" extension.

front.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.t: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

The WebSocket Protocol enables two-way communication between a client running untrusted code in a controlled environment to a remote host that has opted-in to communications from that code. The security model used for this is the origin-based security model commonly used by web browsers. The protocol consists of an opening handshake followed by basic message framing, layered over TCP. The goal of this technology is to provide a mechanism for browser-based applications that need two-way communication with servers that does not rely on opening multiple HTTP connections (e.g., using XMLHttpRequest or <iframe>s and long polling).

This document defines a framework for creating WebSocket extensions that add compression functionality to the WebSocket Protocol. An extension based on this framework compresses the payload data portion of WebSocket data messages on a per-message basis using parameters negotiated during the opening handshake. This framework provides a general method for applying a compression algorithm to the contents of WebSocket messages. Each compression algorithm has to be defined in a document defining the extension by specifying the parameter negotiation and the payload transformation algorithm in detail. This document also specifies one specific compression extension using the DEFLATE algorithm.

front.title: Zstandard Compression and the application/zstd Media Type

abstract.t: Zstandard, or "zstd" (pronounced "zee standard"), is a data compression mechanism. This document describes the mechanism and registers a media type and content encoding to be used when transporting zstd-compressed content via Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME).
Despite use of the word "standard" as part of its name, readers are advised that this document is not an Internet Standards Track specification; it is being published for informational purposes only.
